prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 Imaging
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We wish to re-image all four targets with the same spectral windows in band 7 but 3x more sensitivity and higher spectral resolution to confirm the objects are still there, with the fluxes and positions they were originally observed with, and to search for any identifying line emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have adopted FDM mode here with a spectral averaging of N=16, which offers 9 km/s spectral resolution (vs. 200 km/s with TDM) and the same spectral coverage as TDM mode, and has a relatively low data rate (1.4 MB/s). This will allow some extra flexibility to search for any narrow line emission, in case our sources ultimately have large gas reserviors.

We adopt a somewhat larger beamsize of 1.0" versus the original observations (0.3") in order to determine if the source was resolved. The significance of the current detections precludes a strong assessment from the data in hand. Coupled with our higher signal-to-noise, we will be able to taper down to 0.3" to check for strong variability.

Sources are detected in Band 7 (same frequency as requested here) with
Src S_353GHz S/N Dark 1 0.96+/-0.17 5.6 Dark 2 0.78+/-0.12 6.5 Dark 3 0.88+/-0.16 5.5 Dark 4 0.79+/-0.16 4.9
We wish to firmly confirm the detections to an rms of 60uJy (3x the current S/N). This observation also allow us to look for any positional or strong flux changes from the sources.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 4 Imaging
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We wish to observe all four targets in Band 3 to constrain long wavelength portion of SED. Contingent on successful Band 7 confirmations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have adopted FDM mode here with a spectral averaging of N=16, which offers 16 km/s spectral resolution (vs. 500 km/s with TDM) and the same spectral coverage as TDM mode, and has a relatively low data rate (1.4 MB/s). This will allow some extra flexibility to search for any narrow line emission, in case our sources ultimately have large gas reserviors.
Again, we adopt a somewhat larger beamsize of 1.0" versus the original observations (0.3") in order detect all of the flux in case the source was partially resolved.

Sources are detected in Band 7 (same frequency as requested here) with
Src S_353GHz(mJy) S/N est. S_150GHz [assume nu^(2)] Dark 1 0.96+/-0.17 5.6 0.184 Dark 2 0.78+/-0.12 6.5 0.149 Dark 3 0.88+/-0.16 5.5 0.169 Dark 4 0.79+/-0.16 4.9 0.151
We extrapolate down to 150 GHz assuming semi-conservative assumption of Rayleigh Jeans (would be worse if there is, e.g., FF absorption) to estimate S_100 fluxes. Given the uncertainty here, we require a S/N ~ 7-8, which equates to an rms of ~0.022 (pushed to the limit to fit in 2 Science Blocks to minimize calibration overheads)
Contingent on confirmation of detection at Band 7

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 9 Imaging
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We wish to observe all four targets in Band 3 to constrain long wavelength portion of SED.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have adopted FDM mode here with a spectral averaging of N=16, which offers 3 km/s spectral resolution (vs. 120 km/s with TDM) and the same spectral coverage as TDM mode, and has a relatively low data rate (1.4 MB/s). This will allow some extra flexibility to search for any narrow line emission, in case our sources ultimately have large gas reserviors.
We adopt the largest beam possible 0.98", which is well-matched to the other observations.

Sources are detected in Band 7 (same frequency as requested here) with
Src S_353GHz S/N est. S_100GHz [assume nu^(2)] Dark 1 0.96+/-0.17 5.6 0.081 Dark 2 0.78+/-0.12 6.5 0.066 Dark 3 0.88+/-0.16 5.5 0.074 Dark 4 0.79+/-0.16 4.9 0.066
We extrapolate down to 100 GHz assuming semi-conservative assumption of Rayleigh Jeans (would be worse if there is, e.g., FF absorption) to estimate S_100 fluxes. Given the uncertainty here, we require a S/N=10, which equates to an rms of 0.07
We wish to firmly confirm the detections to an rms of 60uJy (3x the current S/N). This observation also allow us to look for any positional or strong flux changes from the sources.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: During a previous ALMA Cycle 1 imaging program, four serendipitous submm-bright objects were discovered which appear to have no counterparts in extremely deep optical through MIR imaging. Thus it remains a puzzle as to what such "dark" objects could be. We request ALMA imaging in band 7 to confirm them at higher significance, followed by imaging in bands 4 and 9 to constrain their potential SEDs. These basic constraints should help narrow down the possible origins of these enigmatic objects and allow us to place them within the context of the sub-mJy submm population as a whole.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00869.S, Star formation rates for a complete sample of AGN host galaxies, Mullaney
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
